elements.text: PART ONE
QO. INT. TARDIS CONTROL ROOM.
RECAP FROM PATIENT ZERO
A THUD OF THE TARDIS'S ENGINES. THEN THEY WHOOSH INTO ACTION.
MILA/CHARLEY:
[OVER THE DIN] Is that it?!? Are we going to make it?
We're caught in a temporal shockwave!
A MASSIVE EXPLOSIVE JOLT.
And it may yet destroy us!
CONTINUES...
ANOTHER, BIGGER EXPLOSION. IT SNAPS INTO REVERSE, STOPS, THEN DISPERSES INTO A CACOPHONY OF TINKLING SHARDS. LIKE A BILLION
PIECES OF BROKEN GLASS FALLING. THE IMPRESSION SHOULD BE OF THE SLOW MOTION SHATTERING OF TIME.
THEIR VOICES ARE ECHOING WILDLY ALL OVER THE STEREO FIELD.
MILA/CHARLEY: Doctor! Have the Daleks succeeded?
What? No! Never! (HIS VOICE TRAILS OFF, SEEMINGLY ENDLESSLY "NEVER-NEVER-NEVER' ETC AND UNDER...)
MILA/CHARLEY :
But the TARDIS... it's shattering... billions of tiny pieces... turning to... dust? And you... Oh... look at you.
What about me?
MILA/CHARLEY : There are shadows... stretched out behind you. Other faces. (TO HERSELF) Faces I recognize.
What? What did you say?
MILA/CHARLEY: Are we dead? Is this it?
Paper Cuts by Marc Platt Page 3
No. No it isn't. (PLEASED WITH HIMSELF) In fact, it's the complete opposite.
MILA/CHARLEY : What... life? I don’t get it.
It's good luck, Charley. The best luck we could have ever had.
IN A SHUDDERING 'WHAM' OF ENERGY AND A GROAN OF THE TARDIS ENGINES, THE TARDIS REFORMS ITSELF. THE TINKLING SHARDS RAPIDLY REVERSING ALL AT ONCE. ALL SOUNDS BACK TO NORMAL.
HOLD ON GENTLE HUM OF THE CONTROL ROOM.
MILA/CHARLEY : know you're dying to tell me.

It was good luck that I'd set the TARDIS in regenerative mode. The temporal explosion the Daleks created did blow us apart. (CAUGHT IN THE WONDER OF IT) We were fragmented throughout the infinity of time. For a moment.
MILA/CHARLEY: And that's when I saw... (TRAILS OFF)
Yes, what did you see?
MILA/CHARLEY:
There were six of you. But... different.
How fascinating. Frock coats, checked trousers, velvet jacket, long scarf, cricket gear and me? That sort of thing? MILA/CHARLEY :
(FEIGNING INGORANCE) Er... well... Yes.
(AMUSED) Must've been a side-effect of the temporal shattering. Luckily, as every particle of energy was pulled
apart by the explosion, the TARDIS was able to simultaneously regenerate every molecular link. (PATS THE CONSOLE) What a
clever old girl you are, eh?
MILA/CHARLEY : So... everything's all right now?
Paper Cuts by Marc Platt Page 4
Well... we are. But I'm afraid that temporal explosion meant the Daleks did succeed in releasing those viruses.
MILA/CHARLEY
(DISAPPOINTED) So they... they won? They really beat you this time?
They put themselves back to square one as far as those viruses are concerned. It means that they'll still be able to find them, drifting around the cosmos, and use them to experiment on
that poor Patient Zero, whoever he or she is, was or will be.
MILA/CHARLEY : (SURELY) But you'll stop them.
I'm flattered by your confidence in me, Charlotte. But I'm
afraid it's never easy to predict the future. Although the Daleks and I do seem fated to cross paths. (A DEEP SIGH. HE'S LOST IN THOUGHT. SNAPS OUT OF IT.) So... what did you think
of the past versions of me you caught a glimpse of?
MILA/CHARLEY:
(FEIGNING IGNORENCE AGAIN) Past... versions?
Oh yes... I've had... well, a number of different lives...
That's how it feels sometimes. Although, it's all just one big life really.
MILA/CHARLEY:
(STILL FEIGNING IGNORANCE) Is it? Er... what's that like?
(AS IF CONSIDERING IT FOR THE FIRST TIME) Well, mostly... yes, I think it's been fun. Hmm... yes.
MILA/CHARLEY:
You don’t... seem sure.
Hm? Oh, I was just thinking...
MILA/CHARLEY : Thinking what?
Paper Cuts by Marc Platt Page 5
Well, that there are times when living such a long life means past events come back to haunt you. To bite you. But it doesn't happen that often. By and large.
MILA/CHARLEY : By and large? What does that mean?
(IGNORING HER) Now then, young lady. How precisely are we going to go about finding out who you really are?
CRASH IN OPENING THEME.
Paper Cuts by Marc Platt Page 6

FX: GONG SOUNDS
t this time, in the sixty eighth year of the Serpent, the
orld faces its greatest threat. Plague ravages the Empire of a undred rising suns. As darkness approaches, Draconia must
tand alone or perish. rom this hour, no ship may leave the world. All contact with ther planets, including all Imperial domains, is forbidden on pain of death"c.

(FX: SPEECH FROM PREVIOUS SCENE CONTINUES, BUT FROM A TINNY TV MONITOR, WHILE THE EMPEROR AND [SILENT] DOCTOR WATCH)

(ON TV) ©...Approaching vessels will be deemed infected and shot down. (CONTINUES UNDER SPEECH) All incidents of contagion will be stamped out. No mercy will be shown. Draconia lies bleeding, but the wounds will mend. Lean times will lead to a rebirth and a new spring for our broken world.

(LIVE. OVER TV) Red Warrior Captain to Fortress Gate 3. A blocking move, for all the good it will do me.
FX: BLIP. TINY LITTLE FIGURES MARCHING
Oh, don®’t look so shocked, Doctor. The measures are cruel but
apposite, and you were right to suggest them. It is our only hope of survival.
From henceforth, our thousand years Empire is ended, and Draconia is our prison.
So of course, the Priests must have someone to blame. Did you ever hear so deafening a silence?
BEAT
Well, go on Doctor. You can win in one move®...or you can concede defeat to your poor ruined Emperor. Do your worst. Your life is still at my command.

(FX: WATER RIPPLES. BIRDS SING.

IMMEDIATELY THE UNDERWATER WORLD CLOSES IN)
(HIS THOUGHTS) Oh, no! Not Where are they? They can’'
again. Where’s all my fish gone? have emptied the whole pond out!
ct ct

(FX: GOMORI BREAKS SURFACE. THE WORLD OPENS OUT. GOMORI GASPS, SHAKING THE WATER OUT OF HIS HEAD. A DRACONIAN HORSE WHINNIES - DEEPER THAN AN EARTH HORSE. SEVERAL SETS OF HORSE HOOVES THUD ON THE GRASS.)
You there!
(WARY) Good morning, my lord.
Gomori the fisher-catcher?

Gomori, son of Gomori, by decree of the Emperor, you are summoned.
Me? No, look, my lord. (LAUGHS) Gomori ®’s not here. Gomori the fisher-catcher - he®’s in the next village downstream.

(BACKING AWAY INTO THE WATER) Or Gomori the skypilot - the one who moved to the paper city.
FX: BUT THE HORSE SPLASHES IN AFTER HIM.
No! You8’ve got the wrong one! I8’ve got a family, and more eggs on the way!
(FX: THE SOLDIER GRABS HIM. GOMORI YELLS AND STRUGGLES. THE HORSE PROTESTS. WATER SPLASHES)
Get off
me !
This day, the Emperor journeys to Heaven - and you, lowest of the low, go with him.
(HE SPITS) A plague on all you nobles and your honourable ways!
FX: A GUARD OOFS A FIST INTO HIM

4. EMPEROR? ’S BEDCHAMBER.

(TO HIMSELF —- UTTER CONTEMPT) There you lie, father. Dead to the world... or you soon will be. And how Draconia will grieve at

your passing - all of us who grovel in the dust at your Imperial feet. I9’ve waited too long while you drag and stretch the scrag-end of your life over my ambition. So let®’s savour this moment. The hot blade slicing into your cold, hard heart as I win my birthright at last. Fare you well, father‘... ‘Amighty’o Emperor?g...

(GASPS) Ha! (SOTTO) Mother! STI didn®’t see you there.

Be quiet!
Every death, even an Imperial murder, needs the correct ritual. Besides which, mercifully, you"’re too late.

I shall restore the great Empire that he lost!

The superstrings of the Universe are always humming with information and pressing correspondence - most of it irrelevant spam; a lot of it private.
MILA/CHARLEY I thought it might be urgent.
Charley -
MILA/CHARLEY (RATHER TOO QUICKLY) Yes?
- when you’re a traveller on the temporal highways and byways of the Omniverse, being late is never an issue. I can be as late as I likeo-
MILA/CHARLEY O--and still be early?
Exactly. Lateness, like all time, is relative. And urgency becomes a thing of the past.
FX: MILA/CHARLEY BLIPS AGAIN
MILA/CHARLEY What about this one?

MILA/CHARLEY Here. From the Imperial Court of Draconia. A summons.
May I see? Thank you.
FX: BLIP
Ah, yeso-
Paper Cuts by Marc Platt Page 15
MILA/CHARLEY It is important, isn®’t it? It9’s been in your in-tray for nearly a hundred and fifty years.
Hardly pressing®... but perhaps a response, sooner rather than later, would be in order.
MILA/CHARLEY So what does it say?

No details to speak of - just a summons endorsed by the seal of the Fifteenth Emperor, the Red Emperor himself in the Hightieth Year of the Blood, and some co-ordinates - (BLIPS DIFFERENT BUTTONS. PING.) O- which aren®’t actually on the surface of Draconia at all. That®’s odd.

THE PRINCE WAITS ALONE. THE SHRINE WALLS ARE PAPER SCREENS, SO THERE’S NO RESONANCE.

(FX: A SCREEN DOOR SLIDES OPEN. A DEEP GONG. THE TOMBKEEPER ENTERS (HER CEREMONIAL HELMET TREATS HER VOICE, DISGUISING THE FACT THAT SHE IS THE QUEEN MOTHER IN HER SECRET MULTI-TASKING ROLE AS A LEADER OF THE DRACONIAN PRIESTS)
Highness...
Well? Why the delay, honourable priest?
The rituals of the shrine must be observed. The late Emperor is being lodged on his celestial throne.

At noon on the world, your vigil at the shrine will begin. Three days of contemplation.

Kneeling on a marble floor? At least get me a cushion. Do you want me walking with a stick before I’m even enthroned? And Where’s the Queen Mother? She®’s supposed to be in attendance. Send for her now.
She has®-- other duties.

father.

To oversee the accession of the next Emperor.

FX: THE DOCTOR APPROACHES AND KNOCKS AT THE WARDROBE DOOR

BEAT.
FX: KNOCKS ON THE DOOR AGAIN

I once played Sazou - that®’s a sort of Draconian chess - against the 15th Emperor. I9’m the only person to have ever beaten him - which was a bad move, because no-one beats the Emperor. The knack is to lose while displaying as much strategic skill as possible, so that he thinks he®’s the clever one by beating you.
You®’d think he®’d see through that, wouldn®’t you? But it’s all a matter of honour.

FX: THE DOOR OPENS.

(FX: SHE STEPS SWISHILY OUT, HERE SHE IS, SUDDENLY WITH ACCESS TO SO MUCH THAT WAS JUST OUT OF REACH; TRYING TO STAY CALM AND DESPERATE TO DO THE RIGHT THING)
